title: About
text: About this site

title: gt_theme_excel
text:
gt_theme_excel(gt, color='lightgrey')
Applies an Excel-inspired theme to a GT table.
This function styles a GT object with a look inspired by Microsoft Excel tables.

title: gt_theme_excel
text:
Parameters









Name
Type
Description
Default




gt
GT
An existing GT object.
required


color
str
A string indicating the color of the row striping, defaults to a light gray. Accepts either named colors or hex colors.
'lightgrey'

title: gt_theme_excel
text:
Returns








Name
Type
Description





GT
The themed GT object, allowing for method chaining.

title: gt_theme_excel
text:
Examples

from great_tables import GT, md
from great_tables.data import gtcars
import gt_extras as gte

gtcars_mini = gtcars[["model", "year", "hp", "trq"]].head(5)

gt = (
    GT(gtcars_mini, rowname_col="model")
    .tab_stubhead(label=md("*Car*"))
    .tab_header(title="Car Collection")
)

gt.pipe(gte.gt_theme_excel)






  
    Car Collection
  

  Car
  year
  hp
  trq



  
    GT
    2017
    647.0
    550.0
  
  
    458 Speciale
    2015
    597.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Spider
    2015
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Italia
    2014
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    488 GTB
    2016
    661.0
    561.0

title: fa_icon_repeat
text:
fa_icon_repeat(
    name='star',
    repeats=1,
    fill='black',
    fill_opacity=1,
    stroke=None,
    stroke_width=None,
    stroke_opacity=None,
    height=None,
    width=None,
    margin_left='auto',
    margin_right='0.2em',
    position='relative',
    title=None,
    a11y='deco',
)
Create repeated FontAwesome SVG icons as HTML.
The fa_icon_repeat() function generates one or more FontAwesome SVG icons using the faicons package and returns them as a single HTML string.

title: fa_icon_repeat
text:
Parameters









Name
Type
Description
Default




name
str
The name of the FontAwesome icon to use (e.g., "star", "thumbs-up").
'star'


repeats
int
The number of times to repeat the icon.
1


fill
str | None
The fill color for the icon (e.g., "yellow", "#ffcc00"). If None, uses the default.
'black'


fill_opacity
int | str | None
The opacity of the fill color (0.0 - 1.0).
1


stroke
str | None
The stroke color for the icon outline.
None


stroke_width
str | None
The width of the icon outline.
None


stroke_opacity
int | str | None
The opacity of the outline (0.0 - 1.0).
None


height
str | None
The height of the icon.
None


width
str | None
The width of the icon.
None


margin_left
str | None
The left margin for the icon.
'auto'


margin_right
str | None
The right margin for the icon.
'0.2em'


position
str | None
The CSS position property for the icon (e.g., "absolute", "relative", etc).
'relative'


title
str | None
The title (tooltip) for the icon.
None


a11y
Literal['deco', 'sem'] | None
Accessibility mode: "deco" for decorative, "sem" for semantic.
'deco'

title: fa_icon_repeat
text:
Returns








Name
Type
Description





str
An HTML string containing the repeated SVG icons. If repeats = 0, this string will be empty.

title: fa_icon_repeat
text:
Examples

import pandas as pd
from great_tables import GT
import gt_extras as gte

df = pd.DataFrame({
    "Name": ["Alice", "Bob", "Carol"],
    "Stars": [
        gte.fa_icon_repeat(name="star", repeats=3, fill="gold", fill_opacity=0.66),
        gte.fa_icon_repeat(name="star", repeats=2, fill="gold", stroke="black", stroke_width="3em"),
        gte.fa_icon_repeat(name="star", repeats=1, fill="orange"),
    ]
})

GT(df)







  Name
  Stars



  
    Alice
          
  
  
    Bob
        
  
  
    Carol

title: fa_icon_repeat
text:
Note
See icon_svg() in the faicons package for further implementation details.

title: gt_theme_pff
text:
gt_theme_pff(gt, divider=None, spanners=None, rank_col=None)
Applies a Pro Football Focus (PFF)-inspired theme to a GT table.
This function styles a GT object with a look inspired by Pro Football Focus tables, supporting custom spanners, dividers, and rank column highlighting.

title: gt_theme_pff
text:
Parameters









Name
Type
Description
Default




gt
GT
An existing GT object.
required


divider
str | None
Zero or more column names to visually divide with a preceding border.
None


spanners
list[str] | None
Optional list of spanners to style, as referenced by the GT spanner ids.
None


rank_col
str | None
Optional single column name to highlight as a rank column.
None

title: gt_theme_pff
text:
Returns








Name
Type
Description





GT
The themed GT object, allowing for method chaining.

title: gt_theme_pff
text:
Examples

from great_tables import GT, md
from great_tables.data import gtcars
import gt_extras as gte

gtcars_mini = gtcars[["model", "year", "hp", "trq"]].head(5)

gt = (
    GT(gtcars_mini, rowname_col="model")
    .tab_stubhead(label=md("*Car*"))
    .tab_header(title="Car Collection")
)

gte.gt_theme_pff(gt, rank_col="trq")






  
    Car Collection
  

  Car
  year
  hp
  trq



  
    GT
    2017
    647.0
    550.0
  
  
    458 Speciale
    2015
    597.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Spider
    2015
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Italia
    2014
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    488 GTB
    2016
    661.0
    561.0

title: gt_highlight_cols
text:
gt_highlight_cols(
    gt,
    columns=None,
    fill='#80bcd8',
    alpha=None,
    font_weight='normal',
    font_color='#000000',
)
Add color highlighting to one or more specific columns.
The gt_highlight_cols() function takes an existing GT object and adds highlighting color to the cell background of a specific column(s).

title: gt_highlight_cols
text:
Parameters









Name
Type
Description
Default




gt
GT
An existing GT object.
required


columns
SelectExpr
The columns to target. Can either be a single column name or a series of column names provided in a list. If None, the alignment is applied to all columns.
None


fill
str
A character string indicating the fill color. If nothing is provided, then "#80bcd8" (light blue) will be used as a default.
'#80bcd8'


alpha
int | None
An integer [0, 1] for the alpha transparency value for the color as single value in the range of 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque). If not provided the fill color will either be fully opaque or use alpha information from the color value if it is supplied in the "#RRGGBBAA" format.
None


font_weight
Literal['normal', 'bold', 'bolder', 'lighter'] | int
A string or number indicating the weight of the font. Can be a text-based keyword such as "normal", "bold", "lighter", "bolder", or, a numeric value between 1 and 1000, inclusive. Note that only variable fonts may support the numeric mapping of weight.
'normal'


font_color
str
A character string indicating the text color. If nothing is provided, then "#000000" (black) will be used as a default.
'#000000'

title: gt_highlight_cols
text:
Returns








Name
Type
Description





GT
The GT object is returned. This is the same object that the method is called on so that we can facilitate method chaining.

title: gt_highlight_cols
text:
Examples

from great_tables import GT, md
from great_tables.data import gtcars
import gt_extras as gte

gtcars_mini = gtcars[["model", "year", "hp", "trq"]].head(9)

gt = (
    GT(gtcars_mini, rowname_col="model")
    .tab_stubhead(label=md("*Car*"))
)

gte.gt_highlight_cols(gt, columns="hp")







  Car
  year
  hp
  trq



  
    GT
    2017
    647.0
    550.0
  
  
    458 Speciale
    2015
    597.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Spider
    2015
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Italia
    2014
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    488 GTB
    2016
    661.0
    561.0
  
  
    California
    2015
    553.0
    557.0
  
  
    GTC4Lusso
    2017
    680.0
    514.0
  
  
    FF
    2015
    652.0
    504.0
  
  
    F12Berlinetta
    2015
    731.0
    509.0

title: gt_hulk_col_numeric
text:
gt_hulk_col_numeric(
    gt,
    columns=None,
    palette='PRGn',
    domain=None,
    na_color=None,
    alpha=None,
    reverse=False,
    autocolor_text=True,
)
Apply a color gradient to numeric columns in a GT table.
The gt_hulk_col_numeric() function takes an existing GT object and applies a color gradient to the background of specified numeric columns, based on their values. This is useful for visually emphasizing the distribution or magnitude of numeric data within a table.

title: gt_hulk_col_numeric
text:
Parameters









Name
Type
Description
Default




gt
GT
An existing GT object.
required


columns
SelectExpr
The columns to target. Can be a single column name or a list of column names. If None, the color gradient is applied to all columns.
None


palette
str | list[str] | None
The color palette to use for the gradient. Can be a string referencing a palette name or a list of color hex codes. Defaults to the "PRGn" palette from the ColorBrewer package.
'PRGn'


domain
list[str] | list[int] | list[float] | None
The range of values to map to the color palette. Should be a list of two values (min and max). If None, the domain is inferred from the data.
None


na_color
str | None
The color to use for missing (NA) values. If None, a default color is used.
None


alpha
int | float | None
The alpha (transparency) value for the colors, as a float between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque).
None


reverse
bool
If True, reverses the color palette direction.
False


autocolor_text
bool
If True, automatically adjusts text color for readability against the background.
True

title: gt_hulk_col_numeric
text:
Returns








Name
Type
Description





GT
The modified GT object, allowing for method chaining.

title: gt_hulk_col_numeric
text:
Examples

from great_tables import GT
from great_tables.data import gtcars
import gt_extras as gte

gtcars_mini = gtcars[["model", "year", "hp", "trq"]].head(9)

gt = (
    GT(gtcars_mini, rowname_col="model")
    .tab_stubhead(label="Car")
)

gte.gt_hulk_col_numeric(gt, columns=["hp", "trq"])







  Car
  year
  hp
  trq



  
    GT

    647.0
    550.0
  
  
    458 Speciale
    2015
    597.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Spider
    2015
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    458 Italia
    2014
    562.0
    398.0
  
  
    488 GTB
    2016
    661.0
    561.0

title: gt_theme_dot_matrix
text:
gt_theme_dot_matrix(gt, color='#b5dbb6')
Applies a dot-matrix-inspired theme to a GT table.
This function styles a GT object with a look reminiscent of dot-matrix printouts.

title: gt_theme_dot_matrix
text:
Parameters









Name
Type
Description
Default




gt
GT
An existing GT object.
required


color
str
A string indicating the color of the row striping, defaults to a light green. Accepts either named colors or hex colors.
'#b5dbb6'

title: gt_theme_dot_matrix
text:
Returns








Name
Type
Description





GT
The themed GT object, allowing for method chaining.

title: gt_theme_dot_matrix
text:

    .tab_header(title="Car Collection")

gt.pipe(gte.gt_theme_dot_matrix)

title: API Reference
text:
Functions to generate themes.



gt_theme_538
Applies a FiveThirtyEight-inspired theme to a GT table.


gt_theme_espn
Applies an ESPN-inspired theme to a GT table.


gt_theme_guardian
Applies a Guardian-inspired theme to a GT table.


gt_theme_nytimes
Applies a New York Times-inspired theme to a GT table.


gt_theme_excel
Applies an Excel-inspired theme to a GT table.


gt_theme_dot_matrix
Applies a dot-matrix-inspired theme to a GT table.


gt_theme_dark
Applies a dark mode theme to a GT table.


gt_theme_pff
Applies a Pro Football Focus (PFF)-inspired theme to a GT table.









gt_highlight_cols
Add color highlighting to one or more specific columns.


gt_hulk_col_numeric
Apply a color gradient to numeric columns in a GT table.









fa_icon_repeat
Create repeated FontAwesome SVG icons as HTML.

title: gt_theme_dark
text:
gt_theme_dark(gt)
Applies a dark mode theme to a GT table.
This function styles a GT object with a dark background and light text.

title: gt_theme_dark
text:
Parameters



Name
Type
Description
Default




gt
GT
An existing GT object.
required

title: gt_theme_dark
text:
Returns








Name
Type
Description





GT
The themed GT object, allowing for method chaining.

title: gt_theme_dark
text:

from great_tables import GT, md
from great_tables.data import gtcars
import gt_extras as gte

gtcars_mini = gtcars[["model", "year", "hp", "trq"]].head(5)

gt = (
    GT(gtcars_mini, rowname_col="model")
    .tab_stubhead(label=md("*Car*"))
    .tab_header(title="Car Collection")
)

gt.pipe(gte.gt_theme_dark)

title: gt-extras
text:
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
